snippet: Some have received letters asking for a promise to make their products “secure and controllable,” a catchphrase that might mean backdoor access to private information.
abstract: China is reportedly asking American technology companies wanting to do business in China to agree to policies that could require them to turn over user data and intellectual property to government; companies eager to take advantage of such business opportunities must tread carefully given Chinese government’s sensitivities on issues like censorship and security.

byline.contributor: Nick Wingfield contributed reporting from Seattle and Neil Gough from Hong Kong.

lead_paragraph: Some have received letters asking for a promise to make their products “secure and controllable,” a catchphrase that might mean backdoor access to private information.

headline.main: China Tries to Extract Pledge of Compliance From U.S. Tech Firms
headline.print_headline: China Seeks Compliance Pledges From U.S. Tech Companies
